title: Boundary effect - frequency change in thick string

content.question: Two different uniform strings are attached to each other, as shown in the figure. The strings are made of the same material, and the string on the right has a thicker diameter than the string on the left. The strings are pulled taut, and a periodic wave created at the left end (not shown) of the thin string travels to the right. What, if anything, happens to the frequency of the wave when it is transmitted into the thick string, and what evidence supports the claim?

choices.label: The frequency becomes lower in the thick string. The thick string has a slower wave speed.
The frequency becomes lower in the thick string. A wave’s frequency decreases as time increases.
The frequency stays the same in the thick string. The strings are made of the same material.
The frequency stays the same in the thick string. A wave’s frequency does not change when it travels from one medium to another.

content.answer: The frequency stays the same in the thick string. A wave’s frequency does not change when it travels from one medium to another.
